item.title: Student Opinion Survey Analysis
item.description: Student Opinion Analysis End-of-semester feedback from students in my "Intro to Data Science" course at ORU. The responses are voluntary and anonymous, and I usually incentivize completion with extra credit, but I still have only gotten around a 70% completion rate since starting the course (about 18 total submissions). If you're viewing on a phone, it looks better in landscape. Here's the script for this table.

item.title: Text Parsing with R
item.description: Talk about the text parsing functions. gsub, grepl, grep workflow: filenames, doc, looping, cleaning, output use the sos data as an example, maybe grab an innocuous one from work

item.title: My Experience of Data Science in Finance
item.description: My Experience of Data Science in Banking My first career job in analytics was at a bank. My first project was to try to replicate a white paper on machine learning for mortgage prepayment predictions. After a lot of time and effort, I failed to replicate the model and ended up with what basically amounted to a linear model (read: an extremely oversimplified version of the one in the paper).

item.title: DS Section Nav
item.description: Here is a list of my data science articles in the order I would present them to someone who is unfamiliar with data science. Data Science Articles Data Literacy - discussing aspects of data and digital information in general Visualizing Data - how to convey quantitative information Clustering - reveal the inherent "cliques" of rows within your data set The K-means Algorithm - step-by-step visualizations of the algorithm at work Joining Data - methods for joining different data sets into one Bayesianism - why is Thomas Bayes such a big deal?

item.title: Data Literacy
item.description: Intro Data is fundamentally different from information, and information is fundamentally different from knowledge. However, they are related in the sense that knowledge is composed of collected information and information is composed of curated and analyzed data. Since data science is defined as the process of extracting value from data, and what's valuable is knowledge, we can look at data science as the process of turning data into accurate information, and then into knowledge/insight.

item.title: Filtering Data (R & Excel examples)
item.description: Data Transformation At this point in the class, you should: Have run some of the R code I've provided and what's in the textbook Played around a little with the ggplot functions to generate your own variations of the graphs you've seen so far Conducted your own analysis in Excel for Lab 1 This is a pretty good list of experiences for a brand new data analyst. You have a working knowledge sufficient to take clean, pre-formatted data and derive your own insights from its contents with visualizations.

item.title: Visualizing Data
item.description: You are here Packages "In R, the fundamental unit of shareable code is the package. A package bundles together code, data, documentation, and tests, and is easy to share with others. As of January 2015, there were over 6,000 packages available on the Comprehensive R Archive Network, or CRAN, the public clearing house for R packages. This huge variety of packages is one of the reasons that R is so successful: the chances are that someone has already solved a problem that you’re working on, and you can benefit from their work by downloading their package.

item.title: Joining Data
item.description: Introduction Sometimes the goal of an analysis requires you to gather data from different sources. And even when you can get by with only using one souce, it could take the form of several separate Excel spreadsheets from the marketing department, or an enterprise-wide data warehouse, for example. Sooner or later, you'll need to join multiple data sets together. Imagine that you are analyzing your last year's worth of exercise data from your fitbit.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.
